I.  PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.   The technical assistance (TA) will support India in implementing the Inclusive, Resilient, 
and Sustainable Housing for Urban Poor Sector Project in Tamil Nadu, which is aligned with the 
following impact: permanent shelter with appropriate housing infrastructure and services provided 
for every affected household. The project will have the following outcome: access to inclusive and 
safe  affordable  housing  infrastructure  and  services  for  vulnerable  and  disadvantaged 
communities in Tamil Nadu increased. The project’s three outputs are (i) affordable and improved 
housing for vulnerable communities constructed, (ii) affordable housing for urban poor and 
migrant  workers  increased,  and  (iii)  regional  plan  development  supported.  The  project  is 
estimated to cost $215 million, of which $150 million will be financed from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources. The ensuing loan and this TRTA are listed under the country operations business plan 
for India, 2021–2023.1   
 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification  
 
2.  Operation and maintenance. Ensuring appropriate operation and maintenance (O&M) is 
a key value addition of the project in the delivery of affordable housing. For output 1, O&M 
contracts will be implemented with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the project financing 
O&M during the loan implementation period (until 2028). The implementing agencies for outputs 
1  and  2—Tamil  Nadu Slum  Clearance  Board (TNSCB)  for output  1,  and  the  Tamil  Nadu 
Infrastructure Fund Management Corporation (TNIFMC) for output 2—have no experience in 
developing comprehensive O&M contracts. Both implementing agencies require capacity support 
in the development of O&M contracts and modalities. In addition, improving TNSCB’s asset 
management capacity will contribute to better O&M of TNSCB assets.   
 
3.  Required changes in affordable housing delivery. In addition to appropriate O&M, the 
project will make gradual improvements in the delivery of affordable housing. While TNSCB has 
long experience in building affordable housing to replace cleared slums, the project introduces 
important  changes  in  affordable  housing  design  and  delivery,  including  (i)  collection  and 
management of beneficiary data, (ii) protection and restoration of cleared waterways, and (iii) 
implementation of a graduation program for vulnerable households. The project will finance the 
data collection, protection and restoration works, and the graduation program pilot, but technical 
expertise is required to incorporate these new features into TNSCB’s approach to implementing 
affordable housing. 
 
4.  During project preparation, surveys were conducted through a tablet-based data collection 
system supported by ADB to efficiently collect beneficiary data in addition to the standard 
demographic data collected by TNSCB. Support is required to build TNSCB capacity in survey 
and data collection, and the use of statistical software for data analysis, and to improve data 
storage.  
 
5.  Securing  cleared  waterways  is  important  to  prevent  their  re-encroachment  by  slum 
dwellers.  In  addition,  once  cleared,  various  strategies  can  be  used  to  promote  ecological 
restoration of the waterways. TNSCB requires support in developing restoration models for the 
cleared waterways. 
 
 
1   ADB. 2020. Country Operations Business Plan. India, 2021–2023. Manila.

2 
6.  The graduation approach is being piloted in subprojects to sustain vulnerable relocated 
households. The graduation approach is a holistic, time-bound, and carefully sequenced set of 
interventions to help lift households from poverty. This includes four key components: (i) social 
assistance to support immediate needs, such as subsistence and health services during transition 
in  the  relocation  site;  (ii)  livelihood  promotion  through  localized  market  assessment  and 
household-level enterprise and/or employment matching; (iii) financial inclusion through financial 
literacy and improved access to savings and financial services to promote economic resilience; 
and (iv) social empowerment by improving social dynamics, including gender relations, in the 
families and communities. During project preparation, ADB provided support for the design of the 
graduation pilots and needed preparatory work. TNSCB requires further capacity building for its 
project management unit (PMU) and project implementing unit (PIU) staff to implement this new 
approach to ensuring sustainable relocation. 
 
7.  Requirements for project implementation and future replication. TNSCB has not 
implemented a recent ADB project; more importantly, the project is complex, with changes being 
introduced that are non-standard. The PMU and PIU are well-staffed, with 145 positions, but 
specialist support is required in specific areas of project management, supervision, and design. 
Support is required in the form of specialist support to ensure compliant and timely subproject 
preparation and implementation. The PMU and PIU have environmental and social safeguards 
staff, including specialized staff in the project implementation divisions in three different districts 
that comprise the PIU. Similar to project management, safeguards capacity needs to be built 
through specialist support in the areas of environmental management, engineering, involuntary 
resettlement, social development, and gender. The specialist support is linked to the gradual 
changes in the delivery of affordable housing (paras. 3–6). In addition, as the project is classified 
as Category A for resettlement, external monitoring is required. Safeguards capacity building will 
also  be  provided to  TNIFMC.  Project  implementation  support  will  be  provided  to  all three 
implementing agencies, with implementation guides developed that can be used for future 
replication. 
 
8.   Financial management. The financial management risk is determined to be substantial.2 
The key mitigation measures to address the risk are: (i) establishing a nodal PMU in TNSCB to 
coordinate and consolidate the financial information, (ii) filling vacant accounts staff positions 
(footnote 1), (iii) providing ongoing training in ADB’s financial management requirements and 
disbursement procedures, (iv) including comprehensive financial information in the quarterly 
project progress reports to be submitted to ADB, and (v) adopting the use of accounting software 
by the PMU to record project transactions. Moreover, the project financial statements will be 
audited annually by an auditor acceptable to ADB, following auditing standards acceptable to 
ADB. The three implementing agencies require support in implementing the agreed financial 
management action (FMA) plan.  
 
B.  Outputs and Activities  
9.  Output 1: Operations and maintenance of affordable housing assets improved. The 
output will (i) review current O&M and successful practices in Tamil Nadu and other locations;              
(ii) develop alternative O&M schemes in consultation with stakeholders; and (iii) develop O&M 
contracts,  including  payment  mechanisms.  The  output  will  also  strengthen  TNSCB’s  asset 
 
2  This is because (i) the complex financial management arrangements involve three implementing agencies, (ii) there 
are vacant accounts staff positions in TNSCB, (iii) there is a lack of experience with ADB’s financial management 
requirements and disbursement procedures on the part of implementing agencies, (iv) the Tamil Nadu Shelter Fund 
and TNIFMC have only recently been established and thus have limited financial track records, and (v) TNSCB and 
DTCP have no internal audit function in place and use manual accounting systems.

3 
management capacity by improving its asset management systems and practices. Good practices 
and  lessons  will  be  developed  into  knowledge  products—including  model  O&M  contracts, 
guidelines for O&M of subprojects, and guidelines for asset management—with associated 
training for both TNSCB and TNIFMC to build sustainability during implementation. While these 
knowledge products will guide implementation, these can also guide future replication. 
10.   Output 2: Institutional capacity of the Tamil Nadu Slum Clearance Board, Tamil 
Nadu Infrastructure Fund Management Corporation, and the Directorate of Town and 
Country Planning to design and implement affordable housing delivery strengthened. Key 
activities for TNSCB will include (i) support project and contract management, (ii) build capacity 
in conducting surveys and data analysis, (iii) build capacity in housing unit and complex design, 
(iv) develop models for restoration of cleared waterways, and (v) provide technical support for the 
graduation approach pilots. For TNSCB and TNIFMC, support will be provided to implement and 
monitor environmental and social safeguards. For TNIFMC, support will be provided for pipeline 
development of affordable housing subprojects. For the DTCP, support will be provided to build 
institutional  capacity,  planning,  and  development.  The  output  will  develop  manuals,  model 
documents and good practices, and knowledge products for the delivery of affordable housing. 
E-learning modules will be developed and used in training housing agencies and ULBs to guide 
implementation and future replication. 
11.  Output 3: Financial management strengthened. The three implementing agencies will 
be supported in implementing the agreed FMA plan. Key activities will be to support FMA 
implementation,  including  training  in  ADB’s  financial  management  requirements  and 
disbursement procedures. The output will cover the initial year of project implementation to better 
ensure sustainable financial management. The output will include guides for FMA for the three 
implementing agencies.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
 
12.  The transaction TA is estimated to cost $1.65 million, of which $1.50 million will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). 
The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. The government will provide counterpart 
support in the form of staff, office space and other in-kind contributions. The government was 
informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements  
13.   ADB will administer the TA. The Urban Development and Water Division of ADB’s South 
Asia Department will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants.  
14.   The Government of Tamil Nadu through the Housing and Urban Development Department 
will be the executing agency and TNSCB, TNIFMC, and DTCP will be the implementing agencies 
for the TA, which will be implemented over 4 years. The implementation arrangements are 
summarized in Table 1.
